column1: #Text=Firstly, polycrystalline Cu2-xSe pellets were synthesized by a conventional solid-state method.

#Text=A mixture of Cu and Se powders in the molar ratio 2-x:1 (x = 0.02) was pressed into pellets and sealed in evacuated quartz tubes, before being heated to 600°C for 1–5 hours with a heating rate of 5°C/min, followed by a furnace cooling to room temperature.
#Text=Secondly, the as-sintered Cu2-xSe pellets were used in the melt-quenching approach.

#Text=In order to achieve fast melting and quenching, the as-sintered samples were placed at one end of the sealed quartz tube and heated up using a flame of acetylene and oxygen until they melted completely.
#Text=They were then quickly quenched in water or liquid nitrogen to obtain highly dense bulks with different grain sizes.
#Text=For comparison, single crystals were also prepared using a modified Bridgman method.

#Text=The as-prepared pellets were sealed in a quartz tube and melted at a temperature above 1150°C for 2 hours to obtain a homogeneous melt, followed by cooling down to 800–900°C at a rate of 1–5°C/h.
#Text=The samples were then cooled to room temperature at 4°C/min.
#Text=Finally, the obtained samples were shaped into disks with dimensions of Φ10 mm × 1 mm for thermal diffusivity measurements.
#Text=After the measurements, the same pieces of samples were cut into rectangular bars for measurements of the electrical resistivity and Seebeck coefficient.
